subject: Re: [junit] Help,what's wrong with my TDD practice in my daily life?

messageBody:
Hi Cédric,

What you wrote below would make more sense to me if typing was the
most time-consuming part of the development process for me and I often
ended up in the situation where refactoring makes the tests I wrote
before invalid. Or refactoring invalid tests would take more time than
I felt I gained from the TDD process.

TDD for me is a thinking tool, it helps me solve problems
incrementally and I often end up with simpler solutions than I first
thought I would. Of course sometimes I arrive just where I thought I
would with the complexity I thought I would have but I seldomly know
that in advance.

I agree with you that one should always question what one is doing and
look for improvement in any situation.

/J

> Here is a scenario I've seen happen fairly often:
>
> Write test1
> Write code1
> Write test2
> Write code2
>
> Then a refactoring comes to mind and you realize you don't need code1
> and code2 any more, so you write code3, and suddenly, you find
> yourself having to refactor (or throw away) both test1 and test2.
>
> I was simply suggesting that sometimes, the following flow works better:
>
> Write code1
> Write code2
> <realize a refactoring is possible>
> Refactor code1/code2 into code3
> <happy with the result, now we write the test>
> Write test3
>
> Net result: two less tests to write.
>
